metadata.title: Precison Clinical Medicine Supplementary Material Disease control of 2019-novel coronavirus infection in hospital: West China urgent recommendation

abstract.text: China is facing the serious situation of 2019-novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection. The health care institutions have actively participated in the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of the disease. Proper regulation of inhospital policy may help control virus spreading. We developed seven key clinical questions about the prevention and control of 2019-novel coronavirus infection in a hospital, and provided recommendations based on the best available evidence and expert experience. We interpret the recommendations for better feasibility in Chinese hospital. We hope to provide evidence and reference for the domestic medical institutions to reasonably adjust the hospital workflow during 2019-nCoV infection period.

body_text.text: Since December 2019, when cases of acute pneumonia caused by the 2019-novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) emerged in Wuhan, the coronavirus has spread rapidly throughout more than 30 provinces and province-level municipalities in China. To control further spread of the coronavirus, a first-level public health emergency response was launched [1] . The current preliminary evidence indicates human-to-human transmission of 2019-nCoV from person to person mainly in droplets and contact. The population is generally susceptible to this coronavious, and the proportion of severe cases is appreciable, but the transmission mechanism requires further study [2] [3] [4] . The chairs convened an urgent meeting with the clinical and methods expert committees. At the meeting, the specific clinical demands based on clinical work status were put forward through discussion, then were translated by the team into specific clinical questions following PICO principles under the guidance of the methods chairs.

According to the specific clinical problems involved, this study evaluated potential evidence in PubMed, CNKI, and WanFang databases, Google Scholar and Google Evidence priority levels in descending order were systematic reviews based on randomized controlled trials, randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews of observational studies, cohort studies, cross-sectional studies/case-control studies, uncontrolled observational studies, and expert opinion. Searches were continued until both experts considered that the retrieved literature met the recommendation requirements.

Evidence levels and recommendation levels were estimated by experts using GRADE [7] . The evidence levels were high (••••), moderate (•••○), low (••○○), or very low (•○○○). When the evaluation of the existing evidence did not entirely solve a clinical problem, the feasibility of the clinical research problem was evaluated, and the relevant clinical research was searched when feasible. Based on the evidence level and opinions of the expert group, recommendation levels were assigned as strong recommendation (recommended except in exceptional circumstances), weak recommendation (inclination to adopt based on actual conditions), weak opposition (inclination not to adopt based on actual conditions) and strong opposition (not to be adopted except in exceptional circumstances).

Based on the results of literature searches and evaluation, the West China urgent recommendations and practical interpretations, including preliminary and definitive recommendations, were determined jointly by members of clinical and methods expert committees during two rounds of discussion. Then they underwent peer review before publication.

Based on discussions of the clinical and methods expert committees, the recommendations are directed at general hospital managers, infection prevention and control personnel, and clinical medical staff. They are aimed at promoting infection prevention and control in hospitals during the 2019-nCoV epidemic.
body_text.section: Scope of the recommendations and users

body_text.text: The levels of evidence and of the urgent recommendations are summarized in Table 1. 3.1 Question 1: When 2019-nCoV breaks out, should hospitals immediately establish a hospital emergency incident command system (HICS)?

2019-nCoV infection is a major public health emergency. Hospitals, as essential parts of the HICS, should implement emergency responses under the direction of higher administrative authorities as soon as possible. According to WHO regulations, the establishment of HICS is an essential part of the hospital emergency response [8] . The HICS includes incident commanders and teams for operations, planning, logistics, and finance. The goal is to establish efficient contact, coordination, execution, and adjustment of the work system to achieve the rapid integration of resources [9] . HICS should be alert to the risk of mistakes due to inadequate review mechanisms during the establishment and implementation process [9] , and its structure should be adapted to the actual hospital situation. In 2003, HICS in Beijing [10] and Taiwan [11] played an essential role during the SARS epidemic.

Strictly designed diagnostic studies of 2019-nCoV infection were not found in the literature. The clinical expert committee agreed that, nevertheless, the diagnostic criteria for suspected and confirmed cases in the "Fourth Edition" had important reference value in clinical practice and were the best diagnostic criteria for 2019-nCoV infection at this stage. In the future, the diagnostic criteria may be adjusted as our understanding of the disease deepens. The hospital should reasonably adopt this recommendation and update it as the disease and local clinical situation progress.

During the outbreak of infectious diseases, early identification of severely infected patients can allow early treatment, reducing re-referral to hospital and shortening stay in the emergency department [15] . "Early Warning Scores for Patients with 2019-nCoV Infection" is an automatic early warning system based on the electronic medical record system, which was developed based on clinical expert experience and existing clinical evidence [16] . After identification of a patient by the early warning system, healthcare workers can assess treatment and referral indications in light of clinical manifestations and relevant medical resources. This can help coordinate medical resources and guarantee the safety of patients.

A systematic review based on randomized controlled trials confirmed that wearing personal protective equipment can effectively reduce or even block the spread of respiratory infectious diseases [19] , thereby protecting medical personnel and other patients. On the other hand, equipment conferring high protection can be less comfortable and therefore associated with lower compliance; and its use consumes scarce medical resources in public health emergencies. Therefore, appropriate personal protection methods should be selected based on actual medical exposure risk. For example, wearing gloves when there is a risk of contact with blood, body fluids, and secretions can prevent hands from being contaminated; wearing medical protective masks and goggles when performing aerosol-generating procedures can prevent viruses from splashing on the face and eyes [20] .
The following keywords in Chinese were used: 个人防护、 防护等级、防护分级等.

The following keywords in English were used: PPE, personal protection, SARS, MERS, respiratory. We searched PubMed, WanFang, CNKI, and WHO databases, as well as websites of the Chinese CDC, US CDC, and National Health Commission up to January 28, 2020.

Though included studies are based on randomized controlled trials [19] , their indirectness makes them moderate evidence. The two specific protection programs [17, 18] are expert opinions, so the evidence level is very low.

The clinical expert committee was unanimous in its belief that personal protection must be used during the epidemic of respiratory infectious diseases, even though the level of evidence was moderate. All hospitals should strictly implement such protection. The detailed protection schemes constitute a very low level of evidence that may be adjusted as understanding of the disease deepens. Recommendation schemes can be adjusted for implementation in hospitals, or applied in layers to reflect actual conditions for different types of clinical workers.

Control of Infectious Diseases (2013 Amendment) [22] states that "medical institutions shall undertake the work of monitoring risk factors, protection, disinfection, isolation and disposal of medical waste related to nosocomial infections". During the 2019-nCoV epidemic, the hospital should disinfect corresponding areas according to law.

body_text.text: Considering that 2019-nCoV can be transmitted through droplets and contact, which may include aerosol and the gastrointestinal tract [4] , previous research on SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV shows that commonly used disinfectants, such as 75% ethanol and chlorine-containing disinfectants, can effectively kill the virus [23, 24] . The "2019-nCoV Infection Pneumonia Prevention and Control Protocol (Third Trial Edition)" can serve as a reference (Table 2) .

body_text.text: The Chinese keyword 消毒 was used, while the following keywords in English were used: cleaning, disinfection, SARS, MERS, respiratory. We searched PubMed, WanFang, and CNKI databases as well as Chinese government websites up to January 29, 2020.

Hospital environment disinfection is a legal requirement, so the evidence is considered sufficient and we did not perform evidence retrieval. Since disinfection protocols are based on expert opinions, the level of evidence is very low. An observational study of the SARS epidemic in Hong Kong revealed that 69 medical staff who strictly enforced isolation requirements were not infected, and that all infected medical staff ignored at least one isolation requirement. Therefore droplet isolation and contact isolation may significantly reduce the risk of nosocomial infections among medical staff after exposure to SARS patients [25] . One systematic review showed that aerosol-generating procedures (e.g., endotracheal tube insertion, tracheostomy, mechanical ventilation, and bronchoscopy) increase the risk of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV transmission [26] . Based on the requirements of the "WHO Infection Prevention and Control for Suspected Cases Infected by Novel Coronavirus in Hospitals" [27] and the opinion of our clinical expert committee, standard prevention measures should be adopted for all hospitalized patients during the 2019-nCoV epidemic, including hand hygiene, personal protection, respiratory hygiene, needlestick prevention, cleaning of medical supplies, and disposal of medical waste. Droplet and contact precautions are recommended in addition to standard precautions for patients with suspected or diagnosed 2019-nCoV, and air precautions may be necessary for procedures that generate aerosols. Gastrointestinal tract isolation may also be needed.

The evidence level was determined as moderate, considering that the evidence literature is one observational study [25] , which is indirect (downgrade 1), but the results are highly relevant (upgrade 2).
Isolation protection is crucial for the prevention and treatment of infectious diseases.

Moderate evidence suggests that droplet and contact isolation can sufficiently protect against the SARS virus. Given that the 2019-nCoV shows high homology with the SARS virus and that this recommendation is consistent with other guidance, the clinical expert committee considers it a strong recommendation. Air and gastrointestinal tract isolation may also be needed. [28] . Therefore hospitals should assess the risk of psychosomatic damage to patients according to their actual condition when formulating the temporary visit suspension policy. Qualitative research suggests that patients during the SARS epidemic were understanding of visit restrictions, but healthcare staff should still pay attention to patients and their families when explaining such policies in order to maintain the quality of the patient's medical experience and avoid physician-patient conflicts [31] .

Although the relevant evidence is of low quality, the visit restriction policy indisputably benefits the public and uninfected patients and their families. In addition, video or telephone communication can benefit patients while eliminating risk of exposure during a face-to-face visit. Therefore, we recommend that all hospitals temporarily suspend visits. Gastrointestinal precautions may be needed, based on the most recent literature.) (7) We recommend that hospitals temporarily suspend visits to the ward during 2019-nCoV epidemics and that this policy be strictly monitored, after fully considering the psychological and physical health of patients. More medical evidence and recommendations are needed to guide medical decisions in cases of 2019-nCoV infection.

FIGREF0.text: Jinping Xi urged resolute efforts to control the spread of 2019-nCoV on January 20, 2019. He said that all relevant departments and local governments should bear strong responsibility for the health of the masses, and should improve their response plans and do their best to prevent and control the contagion [5]. During the epidemic, patients admitted to large general hospitals have presented with confirmed or suspected pneumonia but also other diseases, so detailed guidelines for 2019-nCoV control and prevention in hospitals are needed to protect the health of patients and healthcare workers. This study adopted the urgent recommendation model of the West China recommendation system based on the methods of evidence-based medicine and the best relevant worldwide evidence in the shortest possible time. Combined with clinical and management experience, the present recommendations for infection control of 2019-nCoV in hospitals serve to help deploy and utilize available resources as rationally as possible as well as ensure the safe, efficient hospital admission of patients to minimize risk of in-hospital virus transmission in the interests of public health and the selection and recruitment of the panel members Weimin Li and Zhiyong Zong, as Clinical Chairs, suggested the topic of this urgent recommendation based on the needs of the situation. The Methods Chairs Xin Sun and Sheyu Li of the Chinese Evidence-based Medicine Center and MAGIC China Center [6] support the methodology of this urgent recommendation. 2.2 Establishment of an expert committee and definition of clinical questions Clinical chairs coordinated the recruitment and establishment of a clinical expert committee according to the needs of the topic selection and the actual situation. The clinical expert committee recruited members who (1) were engaged in a professional field highly relevant to these urgent recommendations, or who fully understood the actual needs of the recommendation users; (2) were willing and able to participate in the development of recommendations; (3) do not have key conflicts of interest related to the recommendation topics; and (4) had a background in evidence-based medicine or were willing to work in accordance with it. The methods chairs recruited and established a methods expert committee based on methodological demands. The clinical chairs and methodologists selected the project coordinators.

FIGREF13.text: Based on the literature and the opinion of our clinical expert committee, hospitals should ban face-to-face visits with patients in the intensive care unit and general wards who are infected with 2019-nCoV. (Family members with a history of contact with infected patients should seek medical attention.) Visits by uninfected patients to infected patients should be restricted, and they should have only one professional caregiver per day. Hospitals should organize personnel appropriately to ensure strict implementation of these recommendations. To avoid loneliness in patients and meet their communication needs, virtual visits involving voice and video are recommended.

FIGREF14.text: recommendations focus on the prevention and control of 2019-nCoV infections in hospitals in China. They have been formulated through urgent review of the evidence and evidence-based recommendations while taking into account actual situations in hospitals. All recommendations were coordinated with West China Hospital in parallel with their formulation, and were implemented hospital-wide with a supporting implementation platform. These urgent recommendations were completed within one week from proposal of the clinical questions to establishment of multidisciplinary teams and finalization of the recommendations. These recommendations are based on the most recent literature and include practical adjustments, ensuring their timeliness. The process of generating these urgent recommendations may provide a reference for evidence-based decision-making in future public health emergencies. However, these urgent recommendations have limitations. (1) The urgency of the task meant that the clinical expert committee was not fully balanced in terms of region, professional background, or gender. All clinical experts were from the same institution.In addition, during formulation of these recommendations, some committee members had to excuse themselves to attend to urgent epidemic-related work, and substitute workers had to be organized.(2) Time constraints meant that clinical questions were selected after only one round of discussions, before which members of the clinical expert committee did not have the opportunity to conduct an adequate literature review or prepare potential questions. (Similarly, they did not have time to undergo full methodological training.) As a result, questions related to pre-screening triage and close contact management, for example, are not covered in these recommendations. If time and resources permit, the project team will supplement and update these and other key issues in the prevention and control of 2019-nCoV infections. (3) A systematic review of the literature was not conducted before the recommendations were developed. Nevertheless, the research team searched rapidly for the highest-quality, most relevant literature through the reasonable allocation of clinical and methods expert resources. The team searched not only peer-reviewed databases but also official websites, which should be updated in real time, guaranteeing the reliability and timeliness of retrieved evidence. (4) The currently limited understanding of 2019-nCoV infection means that the levels of evidence and therefore recommendation levels are genereally low. Original research is needed in order to develop more reliable recommendations. Our urgent recommendations are as follows. (1) When 2019-nCoV infections occur, hospitals should establish a HICS as soon as possible. (2) We recommend that hospitals adopt the diagnostic criteria of suspected or confirmed cases in the "2019-nCoV Infected Pneumonitis Diagnosis and Treatment Protocol (Fourth Edition)" [4]. (Note: the Sixth Edition of this protocol is now available.) (3) "Early Warning Scores for Patients with 2019-nCoV Infection" may help identify severely infected patients based on their actual needs. (4) All healthcare providers should refer to the "2019-Ncov Infection Pneumonia Prevention and Control in Common Medical Use of Protective Equipment Guidance" [17] and "Occupational protection for preventing 2019-nCoV infection in hospital staff in West China Hospital" [18] for occupational protection. (5) Hospitals can base their sanitization protocols on the "2019-nCoV Infection PneumoniaPrevention and Control Protocol" (Third Trial Edition)[4,21], with appropriate modifications as necessary. (6) Droplet and contact precautions as well as standard precautions should be applied to patients with suspected or diagnosed 2019-nCoV.
